results.title: You and the computer
results.brief_description: Illustrates with live action and simple animation the concept: the computer works the same way you do. It is designed to acquaint the audience with a single aspect of the computer’s function and to arouse interest in future computer-related study. Points our that a trained person with a computer can perform a bigger block of mental work in an afternoon than he could in a lifetime with paper and pencil.

results.title: You've Probably Saved His Life
results.creator_credit: Tristram Miall, Film Australia and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description: A dramatised documentary starring Judy Morris and Ivor Kants which is designed to motivate the general public to learn life saving skills such as cardio-vascular resuscitation. A beloved father and husband dies of an acute heart attack. His life could have been saved had his friends and neighbours known how to resuscitate him. An extremely moving film which should be viewed at home, by community and welfare groups, hospitals and schools. This film saves lives.

results.title: You've got to start somewhere
results.creator_credit: Trout Films, Chris Warner and Maureen McCarthy
results.brief_description: Focuses on a multicultural project at Ferntree Gully Primary School to show what teachers at schools with low migrant populations can do to put the philosophy of education in a multicultural society into practice.

results.title: You're under arrest!: or a citizen's rights and the police
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Adam Symansky and Peter Katadotis
results.brief_description: Claude-Armand Sheppard, a Montreal lawyer, discusses citizens’ rights in dealings with the police. He uses an authentic case where trumped-up charges were twice laid against a citizen. He went to court, was acquitted and then sued for damages. Failure to do so would eventually lead to the erosion of civil rights. Animated drawings lend visual impact to the lawyer’s words. This film is a must for everyone.

results.title: You're the Top: The Cole Porter Story
results.creator_credit: VPI-Videfilm Productions International, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Channel 4, Kirk D'Amico and Allan Albert
results.brief_description: A glorious celebration of one of the world’s most loved song-writers. The many facets of Porter’s persona and music are presented in the film by friends and colleagues who include Gene Kelly, Bob Hope, Cyd Charisse and Dionne Warwick. Songs featured include “I get a kick out of you”, “I love Paris”, “Night and day” and “Let’s do it, let’s fall in love”. The film also includes excerpts from some of Hollywood’s most popular musicals.

results.title: You're Telling Me
results.brief_description: Includes excerpts from “The Bank Dick” this is WC Fields at his best. Portraying small town inventor Sam Bisbee whose works (eg. a keyhole finder for drunks) have brought him only poverty. His daughter is in love with the son of the town snob. Events conspire to ruin his bullet-proof tire just as success seems near. Another of his inventions prohibits him from committing suicide, so Sam decides to go on living.

results.title: You're not communicating
results.creator_credit: Callner Film Productions, Veriation Films and Jerry A Callner
results.brief_description: Communication is a two-way process that depends equally on the efforts of the message sender and the message receiver. But too often, interpersonal communication breaks down. Knowing how to communicate effectively is a vital skill. And understanding the communication process and why it breaks down is the key to improved skills.
